item.title: Football passing networks using R
item.description: In this article I am going to tell you what the passing networks are and how to create them, in addition to share with you some R codes that I prepared for that and some examples cases. If you don’t consider yourself a football analytics nerd and you have not seen yet the slides from the presentations “A look into Soccer Analytics using R” and “Soccer Analytics: A data revolution” I would suggest to check them in order to be familiar with the data types and terminology mentioned here.

item.title: Fitting your own football xG model
item.description: Along this article I am going to share some detail which could be useful if you want to fit your own xG model, in addition to its respective performance evaluation and results analysis. What is xG? The xG (eXpected Goals) is the main metric used into the Football Analytics field nowadays. In simple words, it is the probability (from 0 to 1) that a shot has to become in a goal.
